titleStmt.title: Good news from Ireland being a true and faithful account of a late signal victory gain'd by our English forces near Dublin : together with a report of the taking of that strong city Drogheda, and the speedy advancing of our army from thence towards Dublin : as also an account of the taking of several vessels, and abundance of horses from the enemy, of which the very horse King James rid on in the fight was one, which is now brought to High-lake, with several other things of great moment : in a letter directed from an officer in the fight, to Mr. John Cook at the sheers in Little Lumbard street, where the true copy is to be seen.
titleStmt.author: Crysly, James.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 10 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 2 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: Good news from Ireland being a true and faithful account of a late signal victory gain'd by our English forces near Dublin : together with a report of the taking of that strong city Drogheda, and the speedy advancing of our army from thence towards Dublin : as also an account of the taking of several vessels, and abundance of horses from the enemy, of which the very horse King James rid on in the fight was one, which is now brought to High-lake, with several other things of great moment : in a letter directed from an officer in the fight, to Mr. John Cook at the sheers in Little Lumbard street, where the true copy is to be seen.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2013-07 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2013-09 Anne SimpsonText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: Good News from IRELAND, Being a True and Faithful Account of a Late Signal Victory Gain'd by our Engli≈øh Forces near DUBLIN.
Together with a Report of the taking of that ≈øtrong City Drogheda, and the ≈øpeedy Advancing of our Army from thence towards Dublin.

As al≈øo an Account of the taking of ≈øeveral Ve≈ø≈øels, and abundance of Hor≈øes from the Enemy, of which the very Hor≈øe King James Rid on in the Fight was one, which is now brought to High-lake; with ≈øeveral other things of great moment.
In a Letter directed from an Officer in the Fight, to Mr. John Cook at the Sheers in Little Lumbard ≈øtreet, where the true Copy is to be ≈øeen.

body.p:
THough occa≈øion has not hitherto permitted me to write to you all this time, yet I hope this will not be unwelcome to ≈øuch a well-wi≈øher of their Maje≈øties and Countreys Intere≈øt as your ≈øelf. We ju≈øt now Arrived here ≈øafe from Dublin Bay, whither our Commander Captain John Jennings was ordered out la≈øt Week, taking Their Maje≈øties Ship the Dover, Captain Whitaker Commander along for our A≈ø≈øi≈øtance: we Arrived at Dublin Bay about 11 at Night on Friday la≈øt, and came to an Anchor, ≈øent our Boats to and again over the Bay all that Night and to Morrow after, and did take ≈øeveral little Ve≈ø≈øels with Pri≈øoners, and Prote≈øtants, by whom we were too late informed that four Ve≈ø≈øels went richly loaded for France ≈øome five or ≈øix hours before we Arrived; but our comfort is that the Ruby and James Galley being ≈øent before us to Crui≈øe over again≈øt Waterford and Salte≈øs, can hardly be ≈øuppo≈øed to mi≈øs of them. Our taking of ≈øo many of their Barks and Ve≈ø≈øels did ≈øo vex the Iri≈øh that they planted abundance of Great Guns upon one ≈øide of the Bay, and play'd very ≈ømartly upon us all Saturday Morning, which our Men were ≈øo unconcerned at, that while their Great Shot came very thick about us on all ≈øides, yet all we returned them for ≈øome time were ≈øome few Hollows of deri≈øion after every Volley of the Iri≈øh Guns. But at length our Commander orders to weigh Anchor, and coming ≈øome nearer to them, returned them ≈øo hot Broad-≈øides that though all the place was full of Men, and convenience to keep our Shot from doing them much hurt, yet of a truth it was plea≈øant to ≈øee with what pannick fear and confu≈øion they run every one almo≈øt a different way, in all the World like a company of Mice pur≈øued by Rats, indu≈øtriou≈øly making tryal of every appearance of a hiding place. The Hor≈øes run as confu≈øedly and di≈øorderly as the Men, and being madded with noi≈øe and di≈øorder, trod down numbers of them, for though there were a great number of Hor≈øemen (for they feared our coming a≈øhore) yet in a little time not a Man was to be ≈øeen on Hor≈øeback ≈øave the late King James endeavouring to put courage in that Spiritle≈øs Crew; but all he could do was with great difficulty to get their Guns carried off, and was forced to quit his Hor≈øe; upon which our Commander ordered the Boats a≈øhore, and going him≈øelf in Per≈øon, took a little Ve≈ø≈øel in the eye of ≈øeveral Troops of Dragoons that had come fre≈øh from Dublin, with whom, as we under≈øtood after, the late King James returned; but ≈øo ≈øoon as our Commander ordered the two Boats
Crews a≈øhore, it was plea≈øant to ≈øee how ≈øuch as were on Hor≈øeback did Scamper, and ≈øuch as were on Foot did climb upon the Rocks like ≈øo many Goats. In fine, it not being ≈øafe for ≈øo ≈ømall a Number as our Boats Crews to advance far, our Commander was contented to bring ≈øome of their Hor≈øes on Board of our Ship by the little Ve≈ø≈øel he had taken in their eye, for a token of their Cowardize, and the Engli≈øh Courage, among≈øt which was the late King James's own Hor≈øe, which he had quit, it ≈øeems, to order and encourage the Dragoons that were on foot. We brought four of the Hor≈øes, and ≈øpecially that which was the late King James's to High-lake, and ≈øet them on Shore. In all the Action, though they lo≈øt ≈øeveral, as we could vi≈øibly ≈øee, and Pri≈øoners after taken confirmed, yet we lo≈øt not one Man, though yet there wanted not work for your In≈øtruments, which an≈øwered my expectation pretty well. There lay a Privateer within the Bar, which we are informed does carry Weekly Pacquets to and from ≈øome place of England, which we could not come at, our Boats being of too ≈ømall Force to attack him, and our Ships of too great Burthen to go over the Bar; be≈øide, that we was not allowed ≈øo much time by our Orders as to Man and Fit one or two of the Barks we took to attack him, el≈øe our Commander had certainly brought him along. The Prote≈øtants and Pri≈øoners tell us, That all things are ≈øo ≈øcarce at Dublin, that the French are like to eat up the Iri≈øh, and they irritated to ≈øee the French preferred and countenanced, ≈øeverals ≈øpecially of the Iri≈øh are daily killed upon the Score. They expected we were to lye in the Bay to hinder them from any commerce by Sea with France or other parts of Ireland, which terrified, and as the Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure us, would weaken them exceedingly, and make them quit Dublin. 'Tis commonly judged by Papi≈øts as well as Prote≈øtants at Dublin, that King James has a mind to ≈øubmit to our King; Fir≈øt, Becau≈øe he is nothing ≈øo much ca≈øt down, ≈øometime ≈øince he heard of King William's De≈øign of coming to Ireland; and of his little concern how things go with his Army. Others judge that he makes his account to quit Ireland at la≈øt, becau≈øe he is ≈øo earne≈øt in ≈øending off for France all the Be≈øt things he can, and tho≈øe al≈øo that are neare≈øt to him, in the≈øe four Ships I ≈øpoke of; they tell us of a va≈øt deal of Plate, Gold, and Silver Money, be≈øide other fine Things; ≈øo that hardly any Money but their new Coin is to be ≈øeen among them. We brought off a great deal of their Coin at this and other Occa≈øions, whereof I would have ≈øent you a Token, if wo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h the pains. Our Army, as the Pri≈øoners tell us, have taken Droghedah, and make ha≈øte towards Dublin. All the Pri≈øoners profe≈øs them≈øelves willing and glad to be Taken from the Mi≈øery that they feared to come upon them. By which you may judge what may be expected if our King were once over. So ≈øoon as he goes over, our Ship, with the Monk and St. Albans are order'd to attend the great Fleet, whence I may have Occa≈øion to ≈øend to you for ≈øome In≈øtruments, and my Friends Mr. Hul≈øe and Mr. Thowlt, for ≈øome Medicines; for our Captain has ≈øpoken to me to provide for a bigger Ship. I ≈øhall only de≈øire you to Pre≈øent my mo≈øt hearty Re≈øpects to my very good Friends Mr. Hargrave, and Mr. Couley, Mr. Hul≈øe, and Mr. Thowlt; and to plea≈øe, if you can hear of us, to write me how they be, and your ≈øelf; as al≈øo how things Rule, e≈øpecially in Scotland. Our Crui≈øers have been ≈øo vigilant, that it is great News to hear of a French Ship any where in this Channel. I could write you many more con≈øiderable things, but that I forbear to trouble you too much at one time, being,

closer.signed: Your Affectionate Friend and humble Servant, James Cry≈øly.

div.head: Books Newly Publi≈øht.
div.p: ‚òû The Bloody Duke; or the Adventures for a Crown: A Tragi-Comedy as it was Acted at the Court at Alba Regalis by ≈øeveral Per≈øons of Great Quality.
‚òû The Abdicated Prince; or the Adventures of Four years: A Tragi-Comedy. The Second Edition.
‚òû The Late Revolution; or the Happy Change: A Tragi-Comedy, as it was Acted throughou ‚Ä¢ the Engli≈øh Dominions in the year 1688. Written by a Per≈øon of Quality.
‚òû The≈øe three new Plays contain a full Account of the private Intrigues of the Two la≈øt Reigns, and of all the mo≈øt Remarkable Tran≈øactions that have happened ≈øince.

‚òû A Narrative of the Di≈ø≈øenters New Plot, that has made ≈øuch a great noi≈øe in the World by being mi≈øunder≈øtood; with the Chief Con≈øpirators Names, and Principal Con≈øults: Written by one who was deeply concern'd therein. To which is added, an Account of the de≈øign of it by the ≈øame Author.
London, Printed for John Dunton at the Raven in the Poultrey. 1690.
